title: Democrats Subpoena White House, Seek Ukraine-Policy Documents From Pence
summary: Committee leaders want documentation related to Trump calls on April 21 and July 25 with Ukrainian president. WASHINGTON-House Democrats leading an impeachment probe subpoenaed the White House and asked Vice President Mike Pence for documents related to President Trump's policy toward Ukraine, opening up a new front in the investigation stemming from the president's request that Kyiv probe presidential candidate Joe Biden.

title: In Months Before Trump Call, Ukraine Officials Felt White House Pressure
summary: The administration in Kyiv felt it had to accede to White House wishes in order to secure a summit. KYIV, Ukraine-Two weeks after national elections in April vaulted him from the role of television comic to Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky got word that President Trump's personal lawyer wanted to come to Kyiv to talk.

title: Another Former KPMG Executive Pleads Guilty in 'Steal the Exam' Scheme
summary: David Britt, a former partner at the Big Four audit firm, admitted to conspiracy to commit wire fraud. A former partner at KPMG LLP pleaded guilty Thursday for his role in the "steal the exam" scandal that exposed major weaknesses at the Big Four accounting firm, the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York said.

title: Helicopter Company Bristow Wins Approval to Leave Bankruptcy
summary: Solus Alternative Asset Management LP and the South Dakota Investment Council will populate half the company's board. Bristow Group Inc. was cleared to leave bankruptcy under a reorganization that hands ownership of the helicopter transportation services business mostly to creditors, with Solus Alternative Asset Management LP and South Dakota Investment Council playing key roles in the company's future.

title: Hong Kong, Unmasked
summary: Carrie Lam invokes emergency powers to crack down on protests.. The rule of law has taken a battering in Hong Kong this year, and this week Chief Executive Carrie Lam dealt it another blow as she exercised emergency powers for the first time since Britain handed over the colony to China.

title: Pelosi's Expensive Drug Bill
summary: Let's hope impeachment kills the chance for pharma price controls.. With impeachment in high gear, Democrats may not have time or interest to legislate. This is just as well on drug prices, where Nancy Pelosi has proposed price controls and President Trump cheered her on.

title: A Sigh of Jobs Relief
summary: Workers continue to gain, despite damage from trade policy.. Imagine how well the U.S. economy would be doing with better trade policy. That's our reaction to Friday's jobs report for September that showed remarkable resilience despite the headwinds of tariffs, declining business investment and a manufacturing downturn.

title: Charles Schwab, Lennar, Johnson & Johnson: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: U.S. stock benchmarks bounced back Thursday and Friday. Here are seven stocks that moved on news.. Charles Schwab Corp.

title: Voters and Their MPs See Brexit Differently
summary: Contemptuous U.K. remainers demand that politics negate democracy because the unwashed masses couldn't possibly have understood the folly of the franchise they so foolishly squandered.. Joseph C. Sternberg ("British Politics Is Working Too Well," Political Economics, Sept. 27) speaks for elites on every continent when he declares that any antiestablishment referendum win is illegitimate unless voters prevail by more than "a simple majority." He insists that a populist victory is never a true victory unless the victors surmount "a high bar." How high? That's up to the elites who rig the game to raise that bar as often and insurmountably as is required to thwart the popular will.

title: Lessons From the Paul Theroux Interview
summary: Contrary to popular American thought, Mexico isn't a derivative of America. Mexicans neither want or require our sympathy.. Regarding Tunku Varadarajan's "The Weekend Interview with Paul Theroux: How Mexicans See the U.S. and Trump" (Sept. 28): I try to visit Mexico City every year. I enjoy getting lost in the endless variety the city offers. One such trip took place directly after Donald Trump announced his plans for the wall. I was certain this news would make my interaction with the locals less cordial; I was mistaken.

title: Baseball Playoffs Should Be Earlier and Available to All
summary: In addition to the late starts for baseball's playoff games, years ago baseball seemed to start the trend that more sports have followed: cable-only early playoff rounds.. Regarding Joanna Cohen's "Put the Playoffs Back in Waking Hours" (op-ed, Oct. 1): In addition to the late starts for baseball's playoff games, years ago baseball seemed to start the trend that more sports have followed: cable-only early playoff rounds. So not only do children need to have parents who are willing to look the other way with regard to bedtimes, but they need parents who are willing to subject their families to the possibilities of channel flipping through 50-plus stations of Kardashians by subscribing to some paid cable or internet streaming service if they want to be able to watch the best baseball games of the season.

title: Catholic Church: Leaner, but Not in Decline
summary: The Church doesn't have as many priests as in 1965, but maybe it doesn't need as many; it just needs good ones.. In her review of George Weigel's "The Irony of Modern Catholic History" (Books, Sept. 28), Helen Andrews notes: "The number of ordinations per year in the United States dropped by more than half between 1965 and 2002, and the average age of priests jumped from 46 to 60," statistically accurate, then adding, "That was before the sexual-abuse crisis hit the headlines." The number of seminarians and ordinations have remained relatively stable and have even risen since those headlines. Yes, numbers have declined, but is the Church in "decline"?

title: Turkey's American Hostage Speaks Out
summary: Pastor Andrew Brunson on his ordeal behind bars, his meeting with Trump, and his hopes for a turn away from Islam.. Kansas City, Mo.

title: Kentucky's Ambulance Cartel Is Afraid of Phillip Truesdell
summary: Legacy Medical Transport's owner goes to court against a law protecting incumbent firms from competition.. Phillip Truesdell is in the nonemergency ambulance business. When people are confined to a stretcher, need an intravenous bag, or are undergoing dialysis, they can't simply hop into an Uber. They need an ambulance to get around. It's an essential service, and running the business, Legacy Medical Transport, has allowed Mr. Truesdell to keep his son and daughter employed and close to home in Aberdeen, Ohio.

title: Trump, in August Call With Senator, Denied Diplomat's Claim of Link Between Ukraine Aid, Probe
summary: Sen. Ron Johnson asked the president after hearing of potential pressure campaign. A Republican senator said he was told by an American diplomat in August that the release of U.S. aid to Ukraine was contingent on an investigation desired by President Trump and his allies, but Mr. Trump denied pursuing any such proposal when the lawmaker pressed him on it.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Old Joe Biden
summary: 'His basic theory was Senator Boggs was beloved, but these were changing times.'. From "Biden's Most Formidable Opponent Is Not Another Democrat" by Michael Kruse, Politico Magazine, Oct. 4:

title: GM, UAW Duel Over Temporary Workers, New-Hire Wages
summary: Bargainers are trying to resolve two key issues as strike at General Motors drags on. General Motors Co. and the striking United Auto Workers union are dueling over two main issues: how fast to move newer hires up to the top wage and how soon temporary workers should qualify for full employment.

title: Traders Bolster Bets on Lower Fed Rates
summary: Anticipation of sharper growth slowdown pushes investors to bet policy makers will keep easing. Traders are increasing wagers that the Federal Reserve will continue to cut interest rates to stave off a recession following a volatile stretch for markets.

title: Norm Violations Are Now the Norm
summary: President Trump impeaches himself second, Washington's extant political culture first.. Donald Trump is rightly smacked for calling his impeachment antagonists traitors, spies and lowlifes. Unfortunately we don't have benefit of a clear experiment on whether, by now, Mr. Trump or his enemies are more responsible for this erosion of standards. From the moment he was elected, many journalists, Democrats and veterans of the Obama administration were happy to throw around the term traitor for Mr. Trump.

title: Greta Thunberg Has the Climate Alarmists' Number
summary: If they believed what they claim to believe, they'd do a lot more about it. She's right-how dare they?. How to think about Greta Thunberg? She is the 16-year-old Swedish environmental activist known for her articulate fulminations on climate change. At last month's United Nations General Assembly, she scolded delegates. "I shouldn't be up here," she said, her expression contorted with rage. "I should be back in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you all come to us young people for hope. How dare you? You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words. And yet I'm one of the lucky ones. People are suffering. People are dying. Entire ecosystems are collapsing. We are in the beginning of a mass extinction, and all you can talk about is money and fairy tales of eternal economic growth. How dare you!"

title: BP Chief to Retire Next Year
summary: Bob Dudley navigated the company through turbulent times: the aftermath of Deepwater Horizon and a global oil-price collapse. After nearly a decade steering BP PLC through the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon crisis, Chief Executive Bob Dudley will hand to his successor an oil-and-gas giant facing a new set of pressures-searching for ways to turn a profit from cleaner energy sources while cutting dependence on fossil fuels.

title: PayPal Drops Out of Facebook's Libra Payments Network
summary: Payments company's move comes as other financial partners reconsider their involvement. PayPal Holdings Inc. is withdrawing from the group of companies Facebook Inc. assembled to launch a global cryptocurrency-based payments network, dealing a blow to the social-media giant's ambitions to transform financial services.

title: Two Fed Officials Upbeat on Jobs Data, But Noncommittal on Rate Outlook
summary: Fed policy makers due to meet later this month, with markets expecting another rate cut. Two veteran Federal Reserve officials who have opposed or been skeptical of central-bank rate cuts this year declined to say Friday where they stand on lowering short-term rates later this month.

title: Trump Administration Revamps Ethanol Rules
summary: Producers of the corn-based fuel say they'll wait to see whether changes push up demand. The Trump administration outlined a plan to boost biofuel demand, aiming to ease Farm Belt frustrations over recent changes to federal policies affecting the production of ethanol.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Decline After Jobs Report
summary: Yields fell in later-day trading as investors shifted attention to broad signs that growth is decelerating. U.S. government bond yields fell Friday after data showing the economy added fewer new jobs in September than the month before.

title: Disney Bans Netflix Ads as Streaming's Marketing Wars Intensify
summary: Entertainment giants are set to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to promote new streaming services. Walt Disney Co. is banning advertising from Netflix Inc. across its entertainment TV networks, according to people familiar with the situation, a sign that the marketing wars over streaming-video are escalating as media giants battle each other for subscribers.

title: Warren Raised $24.6 Million in Third Quarter
summary: Massachusetts senator brought in more than most Democratic rivals but was slightly behind Bernie Sanders. Elizabeth Warren said she raised $24.6 million for her Democratic presidential bid from July to September, a period that coincided with the Massachusetts senator's growing crowds and rise in many national and early primary state polls.

title: Your Stock Trades Go Free but Your Cash Is in Chains
summary: Schwab made a big splash this past week by eliminating commissions. It's still making money off you elsewhere.. Freedom isn't free, and free trades aren't either.

title: U.S. Stocks Rally After Jobs Report
summary: S&P 500 ends rocky week with a modest 0.3% loss after rebounding Thursday and Friday. U.S. stocks rallied to end a volatile week as the September jobs report helped ease fears about an economic slowdown.

title: Book Review: 'A State at Any Cost: The Life of David Ben-Gurion'
summary: Revisionist historians see the "original sin" of Israel as the dispossession of the native Arab population.. It is only recently that David Ben-Gurion ceased to be, for the sake of the official record books, Israel's longest-serving prime minister. That honor now belongs to Benjamin Netanyahu, even as his political future becomes ever more uncertain. Ben-Gurion's stature as Israel's founding father, however, would seem to be eminently secure, given his crucial, perhaps indispensable, role in salvaging the Jewish people from political oblivion and reinstating it in its ancestral homeland.

title: PG&E Agrees to Fix Troubled Unit That Violated Safety Rules
summary: Utility, in proposed settlement, would pay penalty and commit funds to address deficiencies in program. PG&E Corp. agreed to pay a penalty and fund a $60 million program to resolve accusations that its employees violated state law at least 170,000 times from 2012 to 2017 by falsifying records showing how employees handled requests to mark underground equipment prior to excavations.

title: Walmart Seeks Outside Investors for Jetblack
summary: Retailer is seeking tech, venture-capital firms to invest in a spinoff; CEO Jenny Fleiss seen exiting in case of spinoff. Walmart Inc. is talking to investors and companies about taking over its Jetblack personal shopping service in a potential spinoff that would have the unprofitable venture's CEO Jenny Fleiss exit, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Treasury Inspector General Reviewing Handling of Requests for Trump Tax Records
summary: Inquiry comes amid legal battle over House Ways and Means Committee's request for president's tax returns. WASHINGTON-The Treasury Department inspector general is reviewing how the administration responded to a House Democrat's request for President Trump's tax returns and audit records.

title: Fed Extends Repo Operations Through Nov. 4
summary: By entering the repurchase agreements, or repo, market, the central bank relieves funding pressure in money markets. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Friday it would extend its scheduled lending in the market for repurchase agreements, or repos, through Nov. 4.

title: Vaping-Related Lung Injuries Rise to 1,080, With 19 Deaths
summary: CDC recommends people stay away from vaping while investigation continues. Confirmed and probable cases of vaping-associated lung illness have risen to 1,080 across 48 states and one U.S. territory, according to the latest numbers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. There have been 19 reported deaths.

title: Google Weighs Acquisition of Rival to Video App TikTok
summary: Firework is startup behind app that lets users share 30-second clips; Weibo also has expressed interest. Google has held discussions about acquiring a video-sharing startup that could help it counter fast-growing TikTok, people familiar with the matter say.

title: All The Women's Fashion Trends That Will Actually Make You Smile
summary: At fashion shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris, designers got optimistic-for the most part. WE TEND TO FORGET how many people work on one dress. The fashion machine lionizes high-profile creative directors, who rotate through the top posts at luxury houses in a slick and expensive game of musical chairs. But at the British brand Alexander McQueen, helmed by the hardworking Sarah Burton, one magnificent piece for the spring 2020 season underscored the importance of collaboration: a white linen gown covered in a scrawled design by Central Saint Martins MA students, that was collectively embroidered in black by every member of Ms. Burton's team. Even the head of human resources for the London-based company stitched a little figure into the piece. After the brand's stirring show near the close of Paris fashion week, Ms. Burton invited many of her colleagues to take a bow with her, and attendees patiently clapped as the seemingly endless team passed by.

title: Energy Company Controlled by Indicted Tycoon Files for Chapter 11
summary: Bankruptcy of Agera Energy marks a possible sign of financial strain within the companies that borrowed money from Greg Lindberg's life insurers. An energy company controlled by indicted financier Greg Lindberg filed for bankruptcy, a possible sign of financial distress in his empire of private companies that collectively borrowed at least $2 billion from life insurers he owned.

title: France Probes Paris Police Killings as Terror Attack
summary: Authorities say suspect had converted to Islam about 18 months ago. PARIS-French authorities say a recent convert to Islam who worked in intelligence at the Paris police headquarters killed four of his colleagues in an assault Thursday that they are now investigating as a possible terrorist attack.

title: U.S. Unemployment Hit 50-Year Low in September
summary: Employers also added 136,000 jobs, suggesting the economy hasn't been affected by global weakening. U.S. unemployment dropped to a half-century low in September and job growth continued at a modest pace, signs the economy is holding up despite a broader global slowdown.

title: Trump's Online Fundraising Surges
summary: Raises $45 million online for re-election bid in third quarter, 29% increase over prior quarter. President Trump's 2020 re-election effort raised $45 million online in the third quarter on a surge of small-dollar donations driven by 313,000 first-time donors, campaign officials said.

title: Oil Shipping Costs Surge, Threatening U.S. Exports
summary: Heightened demand for tankers to ferry oil from the Gulf Coast to Asia is meeting shortage of available ships. Gains in oil prices that followed crippling attacks on Saudi Arabian production facilities last month proved short-lived, yet the expense of shipping crude across the ocean has continued to soar.

title: U.K. Lawmaker Expelled by Johnson Runs for London Mayor
summary: Rory Stewart, a pro-European centrist and one-time contender to become prime minister, plans to run as independent. LONDON-Rory Stewart, a Conservative lawmaker who was expelled for rebelling against his party's Brexit plans, announced Friday that he will run for the role of London mayor, the latest sign of a shake-up that is rippling through British politics.

title: One Dad's Search for the Ultimate Urban Stroller
summary: Our reporter and his team of parents pushed, folded and schlepped 20 models to find one divine ride that could take tykes from teething to training wheels. IN A 2006 'NEW YORKER' cartoon, a toddler is riding in his stroller on a fashionable city sidewalk, a yogurt in one hand and a cellphone at his ear, saying, "I'm in the Maclaren, where are you?"

title: French Guerrilla Artist JR on Why Failure Yields Great Work
summary: The 'urban activist' who once erased the Louvre pyramid is bringing his hijinks to the Brooklyn Museum. In this series, we get the inside story from artists about their upcoming exhibitions and installations-plus, learn about their mantras, rituals and what they're up to next.

title: Economists Wonder How Low U.S. Unemployment Can Go
summary: Joblessness is at a 50-year low, but many say wages would be rising faster if economy really were at full employment. The unemployment rate dropped to 3.5% in September, a rate not seen since December 1969. That is undoubtedly good news for workers, but it has left economists puzzling over how low joblessness can fall and for how long.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Widened in August
summary: Deficit rose to $54.9 billion as Americans bought more goods from abroad, exports grew too. WASHINGTON-The U.S. trade gap widened in August as American consumers bought more cellphones and other goods from abroad while businesses exported more oil and autos, a sign of the economy's resilience amid a global economic slowdown.

title: Fed Chairman Says U.S. Economy Is 'In a Good Place' Despite Some Risks
summary: Central-bank leader says Fed enjoys 'significant protections' from short-term political pressure. WASHINGTON-The U.S. economy faces some risks to growth but remains in a good place overall, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said on Friday.

title: Oakland Prosecutors to Retry Ghost Ship Building's Leaseholder Over Fatal Fire
summary: Jury last month couldn't reach verdict on Derick Ion Almena, accused of manslaughter for blaze that killed 36 people. Prosecutors will retry a man accused of involuntary manslaughter for the 2016 Oakland warehouse fire that took the lives of 36 people.

title: Nissan Audit Chief Sought to Expand Ghosn Probe-and Was Shut Down
summary: Auto maker's former audit chief listed some 80 employees suspected of enabling alleged wrongdoing by former chairman, but her effort was quashed, people familiar with the matter said. Nissan Motor Co. 's audit chief made a list of Nissan employees she believed enabled alleged wrongdoing by former Chairman Carlos Ghosn and planned to create a committee to consider disciplining them, but Nissan quashed her plan after a leading target said it wasn't necessary, according to an internal email and people familiar with the decision.

title: The Trumps, the Bidens and China
summary: The upside of Washington's influence scandal.. Even Hunter Biden doesn't deserve the Chinese judicial system. But there is a silver lining to Donald Trump's suggestion that foreign governments scrutinize unusual financial arrangements involving relatives of people at the center of American political power. There is value in a U.S. President telling the world that the Clinton Foundation will not be the model for how this country conducts its foreign affairs.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Review Louisiana Abortion Restrictions
summary: The high court struck down a similar law in Texas in 2016. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed to review Louisiana abortion restrictions that require doctors to hold hospital admitting privileges near where the procedure is provided, a case that will test recent abortion precedent and reveal the thinking of the court's newest members on the inflammatory issue.

title: Presidential Campaign Targeted by Suspected Iranian Hackers, Microsoft Says
summary: The Democratic National Committee sent an alert to campaigns about the attacks, according to a copy of an email. Microsoft Corp. said Friday that at least one U.S. presidential campaign has been targeted by cyberattacks linked to the Iranian government, in the latest indication that foreign actors are interested in potentially disrupting the 2020 election.

title: Trucking Companies Cut Payrolls for Third Straight Month in September
summary: Jobs grew last month at logistics operators tied to retail sales while truckers overall reduced payrolls by 4,200 jobs. Trucking company payrolls contracted last month as a manufacturing slump weighed on freight demand while logistics sectors tied to e-commerce notched modest gains.

title: Givenchy's Clare Waight Keller on Inspiration-and Designing for Meghan Markle
summary: The French luxury brand's first female artistic director, fresh off her Paris women's fashion show, shares her best art, travel and beauty tips. "THAT GIRL IS A TOMBOY," RAPPED PRINCESS Nokia repeatedly through the substantial speakers at last week's Givenchy women's fashion show in Paris. And as envisioned by the label's British designer Clare Waight Keller, many of the models on the runway fit that description, with their minimal makeup and baggy jeans (made of upcycled vintage denim). The spare, strict collection harked back to Ms. Waight Keller's years as a designer for Calvin Klein in early-1990s New York City. When we spoke with her in advance of her show, she reflected on her own masculine bent growing up in Birmingham, U.K., confessing that as a teen she had short hair and dressed in flat lace-up shoes and men's shirts. "I literally looked like a boy," she said, laughing.

title: Shell Discloses End of U.S. Bribery Probe Into Nigerian Oil Deal
summary: Oil company faces legal proceedings in Europe over a Nigerian oil block. The U.S. Department of Justice has closed its investigation into Royal Dutch Shell PLC's involvement in a 2011 deal for an offshore oil block in Nigeria, the oil company said Friday.

title: Trump Moves to Lift Visa Restrictions on Polish Citizens Who Visit U.S.
summary: Poland still needs State Department's nomination before entering visa-waiver program. WASHINGTON-President Trump said he is moving to lift immigration restrictions that require Polish citizens to get a visa to visit the U.S.

title: Women Who Shaped a Movement
summary: Female artists, models and collaborators helped to define the work of the Pre-Raphaelites.. In the 1850s, a group of British painters known as the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood became famous for their lavishly detailed pictures, full of brilliant colors, medieval settings and women with lush, flowing hair. As its name suggests, the artists who founded the Brotherhood-including John Everett Millais and Dante Gabriel Rossetti-were all male. But a new exhibition proposes that women played a far larger role in the movement than has been previously acknowledged.

title: Former Ukraine Envoy Finds Himself in the Spotlight
summary: Kurt Volker gave closed-door testimony Thursday, is getting married this weekend. KURT VOLKER'S BUSY WEEK: The recently resigned State Department special envoy for Ukraine met privately with House investigators Thursday to discuss whether President Trump pressured the Ukrainian president into investigating Joe Biden. It's a life-changing few days for Volker: He's getting married this weekend.

title: Pioneering Actress Diahann Carroll Dies
summary: The actress and singer won critical acclaim as the first black woman to star in a nonservant role in a TV series, 'Julia'. NEW YORK-Diahann Carroll, the Oscar-nominated actress and singer who won critical acclaim as the first black woman to star in a nonservant role in a TV series as "Julia," has died. She was 84.

title: U.K. Government Says It Will Respect Law Barring No-Deal Exit
summary: Statement to Scottish court counters Prime Minister Boris Johnson's insistence on Oct. 31 departure. LONDON-The U.K. government said in a submission to a Scottish court Friday that it would respect a law forcing it to request a three-month extension to the Brexit negotiations if a divorce deal isn't reached with the European Union by Oct. 19, significantly reducing the chances that Britain will leave the bloc without a deal at the end of this month.

title: Street Battles Break Out After Hong Kong Bans Masks at Protests
summary: Leader Carrie Lam invokes colonial-era emergency law; subway operator shuts network citing destruction. HONG KONG-Street battles raged across Hong Kong and the city's subway operator suspended its entire network late Friday as the government's move to invoke emergency measures and ban people from wearing masks at protests triggered a backlash.

title: Cancer Is Still Beating Us-We Need a New Start
summary: Most patients continue to face excruciating, costly and ineffective treatments. It's time to shift our focus from fighting the disease in its last stages to finding the very first cells.. I have been studying and treating cancer for 35 years, and here's what I know about the progress made in that time: There has been far less than it appears. Despite some advances, the treatments for most kinds of cancer continue to be too painful, too damaging, too expensive and too ineffective. The same three methods-surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy-have prevailed for a half-century.

title: Steve Cohen's Hedge Fund, Point72, Tiger Global Hit in September
summary: Coatue, Melvin Capital, Light Street among other funds that posted losses amid style rotation. Prominent hedge funds lost money in September, a swift comedown after a relatively strong run for the industry at large.

title: Mao's Global Legacy of Revolution and Bloodshed
summary: The founder of Chinese communism is resurgent in Xi Jinping's China, but in places like India and Peru, Maoism never went away. On Tuesday, China marked the 70th anniversary of Mao Zedong's founding of the People's Republic with a spectacular display of military hardware in Tiananmen Square, invoking the "Great Helmsman" as the august builder of the nation. In fact, an official revival of Maoist culture and politics has been under way since 2012. Despite the awful human toll of Mao's long reign, the leaders of the Chinese Communist Party under Xi Jinping have brought back into the mainstream-for the first time since Mao's death in 1976-key elements of Maoist politics, revivifying self-criticism sessions and, above all, a cult of personality, now centered around not Mao but Mr. Xi.

title: U.S. Holds On to Measles-Elimination Status
summary: Designation remains at risk as cases soar globally. The U.S. has retained its measles-elimination status, despite a nearly yearlong outbreak in New York state that put that designation at risk, the Department of Health and Human Services confirmed Friday.

title: EP Energy Files Largest U.S. Energy Bankruptcy Since 2016
summary: Apollo-backed driller files for chapter 11 with proposal to cut $3.3 billion in debt. EP Energy Corp. filed for chapter 11 protection, hoping to survive a commodity slump by cutting $3.3 billion in debt under a proposed deal with Apollo Global Management LLC and Elliott Management Corp.

title: India Slashes Interest Rate, Growth Forecast as Slump Stretches On
summary: Reserve Bank of India cut its key lending rate to 5.15%, a nine-year low. NEW DELHI-India's central bank cut its key lending rate to a nine-year low and slashed the country's growth forecast as Asia's third-largest economy struggles with a surprising slump in consumer demand.

title: One Take, and on to Immortality
summary: Coleman Hawkins helped establish the tenor saxophone as an esteemed instrument for jazz expression-and then made 'Body and Soul' a must-play for musicians..

title: Jobs Report Keeps October Rate Cut Discussion on The Table
summary: Tepid wage growth, other moderating signs do little to clarify Fed debate. WASHINGTON-September jobs numbers are likely to keep open the prospect that the Federal Reserve considers another interest-rate cut this month.

title: 'Hippie': A Long, Strange Trip From Savvy to Spaced-Out
summary: The label came from terms for 'in the know' and 'cool,' but-as Prince Harry suggested this week-now it suggests a certain naïveté. Great Britain's Duke of Sussex, better known to the world as Prince Harry, had a message this week for readers of the Daily Telegraph. Writing from Malawi, where he was observing conservation efforts at national parks, Harry argued that it is necessary to "overcome greed, apathy and selfishness" if humanity is going to protect the planet from environmental destruction. He added, "This may well sound hippy to some. But we cannot afford to have a 'them or us' mentality."

title: HP Has No Easy Way Out of Printer Jam
summary: New printing business model won't be spitting out quick results. Cutting its expenses by $1 billion will prove easy compared with the other task HP Inc. has set for itself-getting people to pay more for printers.

title: DOJ to Weigh In on Challenge to New York Allowing Driver's Licenses for Undocumented Immigrants
summary: Federal prosecutors ask judge for more time to consider their position on county clerk's suit. The U.S. Department of Justice is preparing to weigh in on a legal challenge to a New York state law that allows illegal immigrants to apply for a driver's license.

title: Why Good Job Market Isn't Enough to Satisfy Fed
summary: The jobs market is experiencing a natural slowdown. The biggest risks to the economy are elsewhere. Jobs growth is slowing, but that could have less to do with the risks that are bearing down on the economy than with the tightness of the job market itself. It is part of what makes the Federal Reserve's jobs so difficult.

title: A Southern Getaway With an Unrivaled Soundtrack
summary: For music fans, the Shoals in Alabama is the stuff of rock and R&B legend. The recording studios are still there, but now there are scores of reasons to swing by this cluster of small towns. IN DECEMBER OF 1969, four days before they'd take the stage at California's Altamont Raceway, the Rolling Stones traveled to the small northwest Alabama textile town of Florence and checked into a Holiday Inn. From there, they shuttled back and forth across the Tennessee River to the Muscle Shoals Sound Studio, where over the course of three nights, they cut the songs "You've Got to Move," "Brown Sugar," and "Wild Horses," which Keith Richards wrote while sequestered in the studio's tiny bathroom. In his autobiography, "Life," Mr. Richards reminisced that the studio "was the crème de la crème, except it was just a shack in the middle of nowhere."

title: 'Daughters of Chivalry' Review: Silks and Political Chess
summary: For the daughters of Edward I, the choice of a husband was a political act, even though the consent of the girls was required to make a match.. We are still in debt to scholars from the Victorian era, to the men and women who delved into the British Museum and the Public Record Office preparing so-called calendars of state papers-that is, collections of documents and correspondence from centuries-old archives. One of the most remarkable of these scholars was Mary Anne Everett Green, the author of "Lives of the Princesses of England: From the Norman Conquest," published in 1849-55. Its chronicle provides the bare bones of the biographies into which Kelcey Wilson-Lee breathes new life.

title: Doctors Limit What to Tell Patients About Their DNA Test. Should They?
summary: Resume Subscription. The Mayo Clinic is scanning 20,000 genes for thousands of patients to study genes' role in disease. It will hand over results for just 59.

title: 'September 1, 1939' Review: 'The Music Must Always Play . . .'
summary: Titled for the date Hitler invaded Poland, the poem contains some of W.H. Auden's most famous lines. He came to disdain it.. When W.H. Auden (1907-1973) was elected the Oxford professor of poetry in 1956, he was required to deliver an inaugural lecture. In it, he remarked that whenever he read a poem, he asked himself two questions: "Here is a verbal contraption. How does it work?" That's a technical issue. The second: "What kind of a guy inhabits this poem?" That's a biographical and a philosophical problem.

title: Mysteries: Out of the Frying Pan, Into the Line of Fire
summary: James Sallis's slim and affecting novel follows Sarah Jane Pullman, a woman with a complicated past who gets hired by the sheriff's office in an isolated American town.. Sarah Jane Pullman, narrator of James Sallis's slim and affecting novel "Sarah Jane" (Soho Crime, 207 pages, $23.95), has had much life experience before she gets hired by the sheriff's office in an isolated American town named Farr. She's been a cook and baker, served briefly in the military, fled her marriage-and now finds herself enforcing the law in a place that "had limped from rural to urban long after much of the rest of the country, carrying history on its back with its brick and clapboard homes, narrow streets and town square."

title: Science Fiction: Raymond Khoury's 'Empire of Lies'
summary: In this time-travel tale, a modern Iraqi goes back to 1683 to change history but later finds himself on the run in present-day Islamic Paris.. There are two ways for a novelist to change history. One is the "alternate universe" story. This posits that a pivotal event in the past didn't happen: If Henry VIII had never come to the throne, say, then Europe would now be united in Catholicism under the Pope. The assumption here is essentially that individuals determine history.

title: Fiction Review: Jeanette Winterson's 'Frankissstein'
summary: A twist on the classic by Mary Shelley mixes bawdy humor and profound moral inquiry.. Joining "The Naked and the Dead" and "The Sot-Weed Factor" in that whimsical category of good books with lousy titles is "Frankissstein: A Love Story" (Grove, 344 pages, $27), the latest by the venerable British novelist-and, apparently, wretched punster-Jeanette Winterson. Yes, there are three consecutive s's and no hyphen in this title, and the only explanation I can offer is that the hideous grafting of "kiss" onto "Frankenstein" is meant to evoke the shambling, stitched-together monster that Ms. Winterson revives and updates.

title: Five Best: Dennis W. Johnson on Campaigns and Candidates
summary: The author, most recently, of "Campaigns and Elections: What Everyone Needs to Know.". By Theodore H. White (1961)

title: 'King and Emperor' Review: Charles the Great
summary: Unlike other European conquerors-one thinks of Napoleon or Hitler-Charlemagne died at peace with his empire and with his god.. Over 12 centuries ago, Charles the Great, Charlemagne, united, by force and diplomacy, those regions that make up today the core of the European Union, and created a state apparatus to govern the area. The empire lasted only a few decades beyond his death, but the institutions and cultural processes he promoted have marked Western Europe until today. He remains Europe's most successful leader.

title: 'The Life and Loves of E. Nesbit' Review: A Child in Grown-Up Guise
summary: One of the first authors to write for children in their own idiomatic language, Nesbit had an unwavering allegiance to a child's oft-subversive perspective.. The British writer E. (for Edith) Nesbit has been called the inventor of the children's adventure story, in which young heroes and heroines search for treasure, face perils and solve mysteries, but she also wrote about wishing rings and magical amulets that served as gateways to what the novelist Alejo Carpentier once called "the marvelous real." In Nesbit's books the real was magic, and the magic was real. She was also one of the first authors to write for children in their own lively, forthright and idiomatic language, and she did so with such an unwavering and passionate allegiance to their often-subversive points of view that, as Alison Lurie wrote in "Don't Tell the Grown-Ups," "it is possible now to speak of juvenile literature as before and after E. Nesbit." Her approximately 40 books for children have profoundly influenced writers such as C.S. Lewis, P.L. Travers and J.K. Rowling.

title: The Key to Bliss for a Dual-Career Couple: A Contract
summary: A professor specializing in management and leadership wanted to know how couples around the world maintained two careers without shortchanging their relationships. It is the same dilemma she has faced in her own marriage.. I climbed on the back of the old Vespa with a mix of terror and thrill. It was my first time on anything with two wheels and a motor. But it was New Year's Day, I had a new boyfriend, and I was in for the ride. The engine spluttered and we were off. As we wove round potholes, I clutched the waist of the man I had traveled to Sicily to see. The Vespa was much faster than I had expected, yet I felt both safe and unstable. It was like our relationship that way.
